00024 // object/class functions
00025 
00026 /** Use the setup() function to initialize your class by informing Max of its size, 
00027     the name of your functions that create and destroy instances, 
00028     and the types of arguments passed to the instance creation function.
00029     
00030     @ingroup class_old
00031             
00032     @param  ident       A global variable in your code that points to the initialized class.
00033     @param  makefun     Your instance creation function. 
00034     @param  freefun     Your instance free function (see Chapter 7). 
00035     @param  size        The size of your objects data structure in bytes. 
00036                         Usually you use the C sizeof operator here. 
00037     @param  menufun     No longer used.  You should pass NULL for this parameter.
00038     @param  type        The first of a list of arguments passed to makefun when an object is created.
00039     @param  ...         Any additional arguments passed to makefun when an object is created.
00040                         Together with the type parameter, this creates a standard Max type list 
00041                         as enumerated in #e_max_atomtypes.
00042                         The final argument of the type list should be a 0.
00043     @see @ref chapter_anatomy
00044 */
00045 void setup(t_messlist **ident, method makefun, method freefun, short size, method menufun, short type, ...);
00046 
00047 
00048 /** Use addmess() to bind a function to a message other than the standard ones 
00049     covered by addbang(), addint(), etc.
00050     
00051     @ingroup class_old
00052     @param  f       Function you want to be the method. 
00053     @param  s       C string defining the message. 
00054     @param  type    The first of one or more integers from #e_max_atomtypes specifying the arguments to the message.
00055     @param  ...     Any additional types from #e_max_atomtypes for additonal arguments.
00056     @see @ref chapter_anatomy
00057 */
00058 void addmess(method f, char *s, short type, ...);
00059

00061 /**
00062     Used to bind a function to the common triggering message bang. 
00063 
00064     @ingroup class_old
00065     @param  f   Function to be the bang method. 
00066 */
00067 void addbang(method f);

00069 
00070 /**
00071     Use addint() to bind a function to the int message received in the leftmost inlet.
00072     @ingroup class_old
00073     @param  f Function to be the int method.
00074 */
00075 void addint(method f);
00076 
00077 
00078 /**
00079     Use addfloat() to bind a function to the float message received in the leftmost inlet.
00080     @ingroup class_old
00081     @param  f Function to be the int method.
00082 */
00083 void addfloat(method f);
00084 
00085 
00086 /**
00087     Use addinx() to bind a function to a int message that will be received in 
00088         an inlet other than the leftmost one. 
00089 
00090     @ingroup class_old
00091     @param  f   Function to be the int method. 
00092     @param  n   Number of the inlet connected to this method. 
00093                 1 is the first inlet to the right of the left inlet. 
00094 
00095     @remark This correspondence between inlet locations and messages is not 
00096             automatic, but it is strongly suggested that you follow existing practice. 
00097             You must set the correspondence up when creating an object of your 
00098             class with proper use of intin and floatin in your instance creation 
00099             function @ref chapter_anatomy_object_new. 
00100 */
00101 void addinx(method f, short n);
00102 
00103 
00104 /**
00105     Use addftx() to bind a function to a float message that will be received in 
00106         an inlet other than the leftmost one. 
00107 
00108     @ingroup class_old
00109     @param  f   Function to be the float method. 
00110     @param  n   Number of the inlet connected to this method. 
00111                 1 is the first inlet to the right of the left inlet. 
00112 
00113     @remark This correspondence between inlet locations and messages is not 
00114             automatic, but it is strongly suggested that you follow existing practice. 
00115             You must set the correspondence up when creating an object of your 
00116             class with proper use of intin and floatin in your instance creation 
00117             function @ref chapter_anatomy_object_new. 
00118 */
00119 void addftx(method f, short n);
00120 
00121 
00122 /**
00123     Use newobject to allocate the space for an instance of your class and 
00124     initialize its object header. 
00125 
00126     @ingroup class_old
00127     @param  maxclass    The global class variable initialized in your main routine by the setup function. 
00128     @return             A pointer to the new instance.
00129     
00130     @remark             You call newobject() when creating an instance of your class in your 
00131                         creation function. newobject allocates the proper amount of memory 
00132                         for an object of your class and installs a pointer to your class in the 
00133                         object, so that it can respond with your class’s methods if it receives a 
00134                         message.
00135 */
00136 void *newobject(void *maxclass);
00137 
00138 
00139 /**
00140     Release the memory used by a Max object.
00141     freeobject() calls an object’s free function, if any, then disposes the 
00142     memory used by the object itself. freeobject() should be used on any 
00143     instance of a standard Max object data structure, with the exception of 
00144     Qelems and Atombufs. Clocks, Binbufs, Proxies, Exprs, etc. should be freed with freeobject().
00145     
00146     @ingroup    class_old
00147     @param      op  The object instance pointer to free.
00148     
00149     @remark     This function can be replaced by the use of object_free().
00150                 Unlike freeobject(), object_free() checkes to make sure the pointer is 
00151                 not NULL before trying to free it.
00152     
00153     @see newobject()
00154     @see object_free()
00155 */
00156 void freeobject(t_object *op);
00157 
00158 
00159 /** Make a new instance of an existing Max class.
00160     @ingroup class_old
00161     
00162     @param s    className Symbol specifying the name of the class of the instance to be created. 
00163     @param argc Count of arguments in argv. 
00164     @param argv Array of t_atoms; arguments to the class’s instance creation function. 
00165 
00166     @return     A pointer to the created object, or 0 if the class 
00167                 didn’t exist or there was another type of error in creating the instance. 
00168     
00169     @remark This function creates a new instance of the specified class. Using 
00170     newinstance is equivalent to typing something in a New Object box 
00171     when using Max. The difference is that no object box is created in any 
00172     Patcher window, and you can send messages to the object directly 
00173     without connecting any patch cords. The messages can either be type- 
00174     checked (using typedmess) or non-type-checked (using the members 
00175     of the getfn family).
00176     
00177     This function is useful for taking advantage of other already-defined 
00178     objects that you would like to use “privately” in your object, such as 
00179     tables. See the source code for the coll object for an example of using a 
00180     privately defined class. 
00181 */
00182 void *newinstance(t_symbol *s, short argc, t_atom *argv);

00223 // memory functions
00224 
00225 /**
00226     Allocate small amounts of non-relocatable memory. 
00227     As of Max 5 it is unified with sysmem_newptr(), which is the preferred method for allocating memory.
00228     @ingroup memory
00229     @param  size    The size to allocate in bytes (up to 32767 bytes).
00230     @return         A pointer to the allocated memory.
00231 */
00232 char *getbytes(short size);
00233 
00234 
00235 /**
00236     Free memory allocated with getbytes().
00237     As of Max 5 it is unified with sysmem_newptr(), which is the preferred method for allocating memory.
00238     @ingroup memory
00239     @param  b       A pointer to the block of memory previously allocated that you want to free.
00240     @param  size    The size the block specified (as parameter b) in bytes.
00241 */
00242 void freebytes(void *b, short size);
00243 
00244 
00245 /**
00246     Use getbytes16() to allocate small amounts of non-relocatable 
00247     memory that is aligned on a 16-byte boundary for use with vector optimization.
00248     @ingroup memory
00249     @param  size    The size to allocate in bytes (up to 32767 bytes).
00250     @return         A pointer to the allocated memory.
00251     
00252     @remark     getbytes16() is identical to getbytes except that it returns memory 
00253                 that is aligned to a 16-byte boundary. This allows you to allocate 
00254                 storage for vector-optimized memory at interrupt level. Note that any 
00255                 memory allocated with getbytes16() must be freed with 
00256                 freebytes16(), not freebytes().
00257 */
00258 char *getbytes16(short size);
00259 
00260 
00261 /**
00262     Free memory allocated with getbytes16().
00263     As of Max 5 it is unified with sysmem_newptr(), which is the preferred method for allocating memory.
00264     @ingroup memory
00265     @param  mem     A pointer to the block of memory previously allocated that you want to free.
00266     @param  size    The size the block specified (as parameter b) in bytes.
00267     
00268     @remark     Note that freebytes16() will cause memory corruption if you pass it 
00269                 memory that was allocated with getbytes(). Use it only with memory 
00270                 allocated with getbytes16().
00271 */
00272 void freebytes16(char *mem, short size);
00273 
00274 
00275 /**
00276     Allocate relocatable memory.
00277     
00278     @ingroup memory
00279     @param  size    The size to allocate in bytes.
00280     @return         The allocated handle.
00281     @see            sysmem_newhandle()
00282 */
00283 char **newhandle(long size);
00284 
00285 
00286 /**
00287     Change the size of a handle. 
00288     
00289     @ingroup memory
00290     @param  h       The handle to resize.
00291     @param  size    The new size to allocate in bytes.
00292     @return         Ignored.
00293     @see            sysmem_resizehandle()
00294 */
00295 short growhandle(void *h, long size);
00296 
00297 
00298 /**
00299     Free the memory used by a handle you no longer need.
00300     
00301     @ingroup memory
00302     @param  h       The handle to dispose.
00303     @see            sysmem_freehandle()
00304 */
00305 void disposhandle(char **h);
00306 
00307 
00308 
00309 #ifdef MM_UNIFIED // sysmem and getbytes are unified
00310 #define getbytes(size) ((char *)sysmem_newptr((long)(size)))
00311 #define freebytes(p,size) sysmem_freeptr((char *)(p))
00312 #endif

00314 // symbol/string/text/error functions
00315 
00316 /**
00317     Given a C-string, fetch the matching #t_symbol pointer from the symbol table,
00318     generating the symbol if neccessary.
00319 
00320     @ingroup symbol
00321     @param  s   A C-string to be looked up in Max’s symbol table.
00322     @return     A pointer to the #t_symbol in the symbol table.
00323 */
00324 t_symbol *gensym(char *s);
00325 
00326 
00327 /**
00328     Print text to the Max window.
00329     Max 5 introduced object_post(), which provides several enhancements to post()
00330     where a valid #t_object pointer is available.
00331     
00332     post() is a printf() for the Max window. It even works from non-main threads, 
00333     queuing up multiple lines of text to be printed when the main thread processing resumes. 
00334     post() can be quite useful in debugging your external object.
00335     
00336     @ingroup console
00337     @param  fmt     A C-string containing text and printf-like codes 
00338                     specifying the sizes and formatting of the additional arguments.
00339     @param  ...     Arguments of any type that correspond to the format codes in fmtString.
00340     
00341     @remark     Note that post only passes 16 bytes of arguments to sprintf, so if 
00342                 you want additional formatted items on a single line, use postatom().
00343                  
00344                 Example: 
00345     @code
00346     short whatIsIt; 
00347 
00348     whatIsIt = 999; 
00349     post ("the variable is %ld",(long)whatIsIt); 
00350     @endcode
00351     
00352     @remark     The Max Window output when this code is executed. 
00353     @code
00354     the variable is 999
00355     @endcode
00356     
00357     @see object_post()
00358     @see error()
00359     @see cpost()
00360 */
00361 void post(char *fmt, ...);
00362 
00363 
00364 /**
00365     Print text to the system console.
00366     On the Mac this post will be visible by launching Console.app in the /Applications/Utilities folder.
00367     On Windows this post will be visible by launching the dbgView.exe program, which is a free download
00368     as a part of Microsoft's SysInternals.
00369     
00370     @ingroup console
00371     @param  fmt     A C-string containing text and printf-like codes 
00372                     specifying the sizes and formatting of the additional arguments.
00373     @param  ...     Arguments of any type that correspond to the format codes in fmtString.
00374     
00375     @remark         Particularly on MacOS 10.5, posting to Console.app can be a computationally expensive operation.
00376                     Use with care.
00377                     
00378     @see post()
00379     @see object_post()
00380 */
00381 void cpost(char *fmt, ...);
00382 
00383 
00384 /**
00385     Print an error to the Max window.
00386     Max 5 introduced object_error(), which provides several enhancements to error()
00387     where a valid #t_object pointer is available.
00388     
00389     error() is very similar to post(), thought it offers two additional features:
00390     - the post to the Max window is highlighted (with a red background).
00391     - the post can be trapped with the error object in a patcher.
00392         
00393     @ingroup console
00394     @param  fmt     A C-string containing text and printf-like codes 
00395                     specifying the sizes and formatting of the additional arguments.
00396     @param  ...     Arguments of any type that correspond to the format codes in fmtString.
00397         
00398     @see object_post()
00399     @see post()
00400     @see cpost()
00401 */
00402 void error(char *fmt, ...);
00403 
00404 /**
00405     Put up an error or advisory alert box on the screen.
00406 
00407     Don't use this function.  Instead use error(), object_error(), or object_error_obtrusive().
00408     
00409     This function performs an sprintf() on fmtstring and items, then 
00410     puts up an alert box. ouchstring() will queue the message to a lower 
00411     priority level if it’s called in an interrupt and there is no alert box 
00412     request already pending.
00413     
00414     @ingroup console
00415     @param  s       A C-string containing text and printf-like codes 
00416                     specifying the sizes and formatting of the additional arguments.
00417     @param  ...     Arguments of any type that correspond to the format codes in fmtString.
00418     
00419     @see    error()
00420     @see    object_error()
00421     @see    object_error_obtrusive()
00422 */
00423 void ouchstring(char *s, ...);
00424 short advise(char *s, ...);
00425 void t_cpytext(void);
00426 void drawstr(char *s);
00427 
00428 /**
00429     Print multiple items in the same line of text in the Max window.
00430     This function prints a single #t_atom on a line in the Max window 
00431     without a carriage return afterwards, as post() does. Each #t_atom printed 
00432     is followed by a space character. 
00433 
00434     @ingroup console
00435     @param  ap      The address of a #t_atom to print.
00436 
00437     @see object_post()
00438     @see post()
00439     @see cpost()
00440 
00441 */
00442 void postatom(t_atom *ap);

00447 void stdinletinfo(t_object *s, void *b, long a, char *t);

00449 void debug_printf(char *,...);

00452 /** Receive messages from the error handler.
00453     @ingroup misc
00454     @param  x   The object to be subscribed to the error handler.
00455     
00456     @remark     error_subscribe() enables your object to receive a message (error), 
00457                 followed by the list of atoms in the error message posted to the Max 
00458                 window. 
00459     
00460                 Prior to calling error_subscribe(), you should bind the error 
00461                 message to an internal error handling routine: 
00462     @code
00463     addmess((method)myobject_error, "error", A_GIMME, 0);
00464     @endcode
00465                 Your error handling routine should be declared as follows:
00466     @code
00467     void myobject_error(t_myobject *x, t_symbol *s, short argc, t_atom *argv);
00468     @endcode
00469 */
00470 void error_subscribe(t_object *x);
00471 
00472 
00473 /** Remove an object as an error message recipient.
00474     @ingroup misc
00475     @param  x   The object to unsubscribe. 
00476 */
00477 void error_unsubscribe(t_object *x);

00500 /**
00501     Print text to the Max window, linked to an instance of your object.
00502 
00503     Max window rows which are generated using object_post() or object_error() can be
00504     double-clicked by the user to have Max assist with locating the object in a patcher.
00505     Rows created with object_post() and object_error() will also automatically provide
00506     the name of the object's class in the correct column in the Max window.
00507         
00508     @ingroup console
00509     @param  x       A pointer to your object.
00510     @param  s       A C-string containing text and printf-like codes 
00511                     specifying the sizes and formatting of the additional arguments.
00512     @param  ...     Arguments of any type that correspond to the format codes in fmtString.
00513     
00514     @remark         Example: 
00515     @code
00516     void myMethod(myObject *x, long someArgument)
00517     {
00518         object_post((t_object*)x, "This is my argument: %ld", someArgument);
00519     }
00520     @endcode
00521         
00522     @see object_error()
00523 */
00524 void object_post(t_object *x, char *s, ...);
00525 
00526 
00527 /**
00528     Print text to the Max window, linked to an instance of your object,
00529     and flagged as an error (highlighted with a red background).
00530 
00531     Max window rows which are generated using object_post() or object_error() can be
00532     double-clicked by the user to have Max assist with locating the object in a patcher.
00533     Rows created with object_post() and object_error() will also automatically provide
00534     the name of the object's class in the correct column in the Max window.
00535         
00536     @ingroup console
00537     @param  x       A pointer to your object.
00538     @param  s       A C-string containing text and printf-like codes 
00539                     specifying the sizes and formatting of the additional arguments.
00540     @param  ...     Arguments of any type that correspond to the format codes in fmtString.
00541         
00542     @see object_post()
00543     @see object_warn()
00544 */
00545 void object_error(t_object *x, char *s, ...);
00546

00548 /**
00549     Print text to the Max window, linked to an instance of your object,
00550     and flagged as a warning (highlighted with a yellow background).
00551 
00552     Max window rows which are generated using object_post(), object_error(), or object_warn can be
00553     double-clicked by the user to have Max assist with locating the object in a patcher.
00554     Rows created with object_post(), object_error(), or object_warn() will also automatically provide
00555     the name of the object's class in the correct column in the Max window.
00556         
00557     @ingroup console
00558     @param  x       A pointer to your object.
00559     @param  s       A C-string containing text and printf-like codes 
00560                     specifying the sizes and formatting of the additional arguments.
00561     @param  ...     Arguments of any type that correspond to the format codes in fmtString.
00562             
00563     @see object_post()
00564     @see object_error()
00565 */
00566 void object_warn(t_object *x, char *s, ...);

00580     This function should be used exceedingly sparingly, with preference given to

00586                     specifying the sizes and formatting of the additional arguments.

00602 
00603 
00604 // inlet/outlet functions
00605 
00606 /**
00607     Use inlet_new() to create an inlet that can receive a specific message or any message. 
00608 
00609     @ingroup inout
00610     @param  x   Your object. 
00611     @param  s   Character string of the message, or NULL to receive any message.
00612     @return     A pointer to the new inlet.
00613 
00614     @remark     inlet_new() ceates a general purpose inlet. 
00615                 You can use it in circumstances where you would like special messages to be received in 
00616                 inlets other than the leftmost one. 
00617                 To create an inlet that receives a particular message, pass the message’s 
00618                 character string. For example, to create an inlet that receives only bang 
00619                 messages, do the following
00620     @code
00621     inlet_new (myObject,"bang"); 
00622     @endcode
00623 
00624     @remark     To create an inlet that can receive any message, pass NULL for msg
00625     @code
00626     inlet_new (myObject, NULL); 
00627     @endcode
00628 
00629     @remark     Proxies are an alternative method for general-purpose inlets that have 
00630                 a number of advantages. If you create multiple inlets as shown above, 
00631                 there would be no way to figure out which inlet received a message. See 
00632                 the discussion in @ref chapter_inout_proxies. 
00633 */
00634 void *inlet_new(void *x, char *s);
00635 
00636 /**
00637     Use intin() to create an inlet typed to receive only integers. 
00638 
00639     @ingroup inout
00640     @param  x   Your object. 
00641     @param  n   Location of the inlet from 1 to 9. 1 is immediately to the right of the leftmost inlet. 
00642     @return     A pointer to the new inlet.
00643     
00644     @remark     intin creates integer inlets. 
00645                 It takes a pointer to your newly created object and an integer n, from 1 to 9. 
00646                 The number specifies the message 
00647                 type you’ll get, so you can distinguish one inlet from another. For 
00648                 example, an integer sent in inlet 1 will be of message type in1 and a 
00649                 floating point number sent in inlet 4 will be of type ft4. You use 
00650                 addinx() and addftx() to add methods to respond to these messages.
00651                 
00652                 The order you create additional inlets is important. If you want the 
00653                 rightmost inlet to be the have the highest number in- or ft- message 
00654                 (which is usually the case), you should create the highest number 
00655                 message inlet first. 
00656 */
00657 void *intin(void *x, short n);
00658 
00659 
00660 /**
00661     Use floatin() to create an inlet typed to receive only floats. 
00662 
00663     @ingroup inout
00664     @param  x   Your object. 
00665     @param  n   Location of the inlet from 1 to 9. 1 is immediately to the right of the leftmost inlet. 
00666     @return     A pointer to the new inlet.
00667 */
00668 void *floatin(void *x, short n);
00669 
00670 
00671 /**
00672     Use outlet_new() to create an outlet that can send a specific non-standard message, or any message.
00673 
00674     @ingroup    inout
00675     @param  x   Your object.
00676     @param  s   A C-string specifying the message that will be sent out this outlet, 
00677                 or NULL to indicate the outlet will be used to send various messages.
00678                 The advantage of this kind of outlet’s flexibility is balanced by the fact that 
00679                 Max must perform a message-lookup in real-time for every message sent through it, 
00680                 rather than when a patch is being constructed, as is true for other types of outlets. 
00681                 Patchers execute faster when outlets are typed, since the message 
00682                 lookup can be done before the program executes.
00683     @return     A pointer to the new outlet.
00684 */
00685 void *outlet_new(void *x, char *s);
00686 
00687 
00688 /**
00689     Use bangout() to create an outlet that will always send the bang message. 
00690 
00691     @ingroup    inout
00692     @param  x   Your object.
00693     @return     A pointer to the new outlet.
00694 
00695     @remark     You can send a bang message out a general purpose outlet, but creating 
00696                 an outlet using bangout() allows Max to type-check the connection a 
00697                 user might make and refuse to connect the outlet to any object that 
00698                 cannot receive a bang message. bangout() returns the created outlet. 
00699 */
00700 void *bangout(void *x);
00701 
00702 
00703 /**
00704     Use intout() to create an outlet that will always send the int message. 
00705 
00706     @ingroup    inout
00707     @param  x   Your object.
00708     @return     A pointer to the new outlet.
00709 
00710     @remark     You can send a bang message out a general purpose outlet, but creating 
00711                 an outlet using bangout() allows Max to type-check the connection a 
00712                 user might make and refuse to connect the outlet to any object that 
00713                 cannot receive a bang message. bangout() returns the created outlet. 
00714 */
00715 void *intout(void *x);
00716 
00717 
00718 /**
00719     Use floatout() to create an outlet that will always send the float message. 
00720 
00721     @ingroup    inout
00722     @param  x   Your object.
00723     @return     A pointer to the new outlet.
00724 */
00725 void *floatout(void *x);
00726 
00727 
00728 /**
00729     Use listout() to create an outlet that will always send the list message. 
00730     @ingroup    inout
00731     @param  x   Your object.
00732     @return     A pointer to the new outlet.
00733 */
00734 void *listout(void *x);
00735 
00736 
00737 /**
00738     Use outlet_bang() to send a bang message out an outlet. 
00739 
00740     @ingroup inout
00741     @param  o   Outlet that will send the message.
00742     @return     Returns 0 if a stack overflow occurred, otherwise returns 1.
00743 */
00744 void *outlet_bang(void *o);
00745 
00746 
00747 /**
00748     Use outlet_int() to send a float message out an outlet. 
00749 
00750     @ingroup inout
00751     @param  o   Outlet that will send the message.
00752     @param  n   Integer value to send.
00753     @return     Returns 0 if a stack overflow occurred, otherwise returns 1.
00754 */
00755 void *outlet_int(void *o, long n);
00756 
00757 
00758 /**
00759     Use outlet_float() to send an int message out an outlet. 
00760 
00761     @ingroup inout
00762     @param  o   Outlet that will send the message.
00763     @param  f   Float value to send.
00764     @return     Returns 0 if a stack overflow occurred, otherwise returns 1.
00765 */
00766 void *outlet_float(void *o, double f);
00767 
00768 
00769 /**
00770     Use outlet_list() to send a list message out an outlet. 
00771 
00772     @ingroup inout
00773     @param  o       Outlet that will send the message.
00774     @param  s       Should be NULL, but can be the _sym_list.
00775     @param  ac      Number of elements in the list in argv. 
00776     @param  av      Atoms constituting the list. 
00777     @return         Returns 0 if a stack overflow occurred, otherwise returns 1.
00778     
00779     @remark         outlet_list() sends the list specified by argv and argc out the 
00780                     specified outlet. The outlet must have been created with listout or 
00781                     outlet_new in your object creation function (see above). You create 
00782                     the list as an array of Atoms, but the first item in the list must be an 
00783                     integer or float.
00784                     
00785                     Here’s an example of sending a list of three numbers. 
00786     @code
00787     t_atom myList[3]; 
00788     long theNumbers[3]; 
00789     short i; 
00790     
00791     theNumbers[0] = 23; 
00792     theNumbers[1] = 12; 
00793     theNumbers[2] = 5;
00794     for (i=0; i < 3; i++) { 
00795         atom_setlong(myList+i,theNumbers[i]);
00796     } 
00797     outlet_list(myOutlet,0L,3,&myList); 
00798     @endcode
00799 
00800     @remark         It’s not a good idea to pass large lists to outlet_list that are 
00801                     comprised of local (automatic) variables. If the list is small, as in the 
00802                     above example, there’s no problem. If your object will regularly send 
00803                     lists, it might make sense to keep an array of t_atoms inside your 
00804                     object’s data structure.  
00805 */
00806 void *outlet_list(void *o, t_symbol *s, short ac, t_atom *av);
00807 
00808 
00809 /**
00810     Use outlet_anything() to send any message out an outlet. 
00811 
00812     @ingroup inout
00813     @param  o       Outlet that will send the message.
00814     @param  s       The message selector #t_symbol*. 
00815     @param  ac      Number of elements in the list in argv. 
00816     @param  av      Atoms constituting the list. 
00817     @return         Returns 0 if a stack overflow occurred, otherwise returns 1.
00818     
00819     @remark         This function lets you send an arbitrary message out an outlet. 
00820                     Here are a couple of examples of its use.
00821                     
00822                     First, here’s a hard way to send the bang message (see outlet_bang() for an easier way):
00823     @code
00824     outlet_anything(myOutlet, gensym("bang"), 0, NIL); 
00825     @endcode
00826     
00827     @remark         And here’s an even harder way to send a single integer (instead of using outlet_int()).
00828     @code
00829     t_atom myNumber; 
00830 
00831     atom_setlong(&myNumber, 432);
00832     outlet_anything(myOutlet, gensym("int"), 1, &myNumber);
00833     @endcode
00834 
00835     @remark         Notice that outlet_anything() expects the message argument as a 
00836                     #t_symbol*, so you must use gensym() on a character string. 
00837                 
00838                     If you’ll be sending the same message a lot, you might call gensym() on the message string at 
00839                     initialization time and store the result in a global variable to save the 
00840                     (significant) overhead of calling gensym() every time you want to send a 
00841                     message.
00842                     
00843                     Also, do not send lists using outlet_anything() with list as 
00844                     the selector argument. Use the outlet_list() function instead. 
00845 */
00846 void *outlet_anything(void *o, t_symbol *s, short ac, t_atom *av);
00847 
00848 
00849 void *inlet4(void *x, void *w, char *s, char *s1);
00850 
00851 
00852 void inlet_to(void *x, void *w);
00853 
00854 
00855 short outlet_add(void *x, void *ip);
00856 
00857 
00858 void outlet_rm(void *x, void *ip);
00859 
00860 
00861 void outlet_atoms(void *out, short argc, t_atom *argv);

00866 // clock functions

00868 /**
00869     Create a new Clock object. 
00870     Normally, clock_new() is called in your instance creation 
00871     function—and it cannot be called from a thread other than the main thread. 
00872     To get rid of a clock object you created, use freeobject().
00873 
00874     @ingroup clocks
00875     @param  obj     Argument that will be passed to clock function fn when it is called. 
00876                     This will almost always be a pointer to your object.
00877     @param  fn      Function to be called when the clock goes off, 
00878                     declared to take a single argument as shown in @ref clocks_using_clocks.
00879     @return         A pointer to a newly created Clock object.
00880 */
00881 void *clock_new(void *obj, method fn);
00882 
00883 
00884 void clock_set(void *obj,long when);
00885 
00886 
00887 /**
00888     Schedule the execution of a Clock.
00889     clock_delay() sets a clock to go off at a certain number of 
00890     milliseconds from the current logical time.
00891 
00892     @ingroup clocks
00893     @param  x       Clock to schedule. 
00894     @param  n       Delay, in milliseconds, before the Clock will execute.
00895     @see    clock_fdelay()
00896 */
00897 void clock_delay(void *x, long n);
00898 
00899 
00900 /**
00901     Cancel the scheduled execution of a Clock. 
00902     clock_unset() will do nothing (and not complain) if the Clock passed 
00903     to it has not been set.
00904         
00905     @ingroup clocks
00906     @param  x       Clock to cancel. 
00907 */
00908 void clock_unset(void *x);
00909 void clock_xdelay(void *x, long n);
00910 void clock_xset(void *x, long n);
00911 void clock_xunset(void *x);
00912 short clock_getextfmt(void);
00913 
00914 
00915 /**
00916     Schedule the execution of a Clock using a floating-point argument.
00917     clock_delay() sets a clock to go off at a certain number of 
00918     milliseconds from the current logical time.
00919 
00920     @ingroup clocks
00921     @param  c       Clock to schedule. 
00922     @param  time    Delay, in milliseconds, before the Clock will execute.
00923     @see    clock_delay()
00924 */
00925 void clock_fdelay(void *c, double time);
00926 void clock_fset(void *x, double when);
00927 void clock_fset2(void *x, double when, double offset);
00928 void clock_fdelay(void *x, double f);
00929 void clock_fdelay2(void *x, double delay, double offset);
00930 
00931 
00932 /**
00933     Find out the current logical time of the scheduler in milliseconds
00934     as a floating-point number.
00935 
00936     @ingroup clocks
00937     @param  time    Returns the current time.
00938     @see    gettime()
00939     @see    setclock_getftime()
00940     @see    setclock_gettime()
00941 */
00942 void clock_getftime(double *time);
00943 
00944 
00945 /** Schedule a Clock on a scheduler. 
00946     Schedules the Clock c to execute at time units after the current 
00947     time. If scheduler x is 0 or does not point to a setclock object, the 
00948     internal millisecond scheduler is used. Otherwise c is scheduled on 
00949     the setclock object’s list of Clocks. The Clock should be created with 
00950     clock_new(), the same as for a Clock passed to clock_delay().
00951 
00952     @ingroup clocks
00953     @param  x       A setclock object to be used for scheduling this clock.
00954     @param  c       Clock object containing the function to be executed.
00955     @param  time    Time delay (in the units of the Setclock) from the 
00956                     current time when the Clock will be executed.
00957     @see    @ref    setclock
00958     @see            setclock_fdelay()
00959 */
00960 void setclock_delay(t_object *x, void *c, long time);
00961 
00962 
00963 /** Remove a Clock from a scheduler.
00964     This function unschedules the Clock c in the list of Clocks in the 
00965     setclock object x, or the internal millisecond scheduler if scheduler is 0.
00966 
00967     @ingroup clocks
00968     @param  x       The setclock object that was used to schedule this clock. 
00969                     If 0, the clock is unscheduled from the internal millisecond scheduler.
00970     @param  c       Clock object to be removed from the scheduler.
00971     @see    @ref    setclock
00972 */
00973 void setclock_unset(t_object *x, void *c);
00974 
00975 
00976 /** Find out the current time value of a setclock object.
00977     @ingroup clocks
00978     @param  x       A setclock object. 
00979     @return         Returns the current time value of the setclock object scheduler. 
00980                     If scheduler is 0, setclock_gettime is equivalent to the function 
00981                     gettime that returns the current value of the internal millisecond clock.
00982     @see    @ref    setclock
00983     @see            setclock_getftime()
00984 */
00985 long setclock_gettime(t_object *x);
00986 
00987 
00988 /** Schedule a Clock on a scheduler, using a floating-point time argument.
00989     @ingroup clocks
00990     @param  s       A setclock object to be used for scheduling this clock.
00991     @param  c       Clock object containing the function to be executed.
00992     @param  time    Time delay (in the units of the Setclock) from the 
00993                     current time when the Clock will be executed.
00994     @see    @ref    setclock
00995     @see            setclock_delay()
00996 */
00997 void setclock_fdelay(t_object *s, void *c, double time);

01014 
01015 // scheduler functions
01016 
01017 /**
01018     Find out the current logical time of the scheduler in milliseconds.
01019     
01020     @ingroup    clocks
01021     @return     Returns the current time.
01022     @see        clock_getftime()
01023 */
01024 long gettime(void);
01025 long getschedtime(void);
01026 long getexttime(void);
01027 void sched_suspend(void);
01028 void sched_resume(void);
01029 
01030 
01031 /**
01032     Cause a function to be executed at the timer level at some time in the future.
01033 
01034     @ingroup    threading
01035     @param      ob      First argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01036     @param      fun     Function to be called, see below for how it should be declared.
01037     @param      when    The logical time that the function fun will be executed.
01038     @param      sym     Second argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01039     @param      argc    Count of arguments in argv. argc is also the third argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01040     @param      argv    Array containing a variable number of #t_atom function arguments. 
01041                         If this argument is non-zero, defer allocates memory to make a copy of the arguments 
01042                         (according to the size passed in argc) 
01043                         and passes the copied array to the function fun when it executes as the fourth argument.
01044 
01045     @remark             schedule() calls a function at some time in the future. Unlike defer(), 
01046                         the function is called in the scheduling loop when logical time is equal 
01047                         to the specified value when. This means that the function could be 
01048                         called at interrupt level, so it should follow the usual restrictions on
01049                         interrupt-level conduct. The function fun passed to schedule should 
01050                         be declared as follows: 
01051     
01052     @code                   
01053     void myobject_do (myObject *client, t_symbol *s, short argc, t_atom *argv); 
01054     @endcode
01055     
01056     @remark             One use of schedule() is as an alternative to using the lockout flag.   
01057 
01058     @see        defer()
01059 */
01060 void schedule(void *ob, method fun, long when, t_symbol *sym, short argc, Atom *argv);
01061 void schedulef(void *ob, method fun, double when, t_symbol *sym, short argc, Atom *argv);
01062 
01063 
01064 
01065 
01066 /** Create a new local scheduler.
01067     @ingroup        clocks
01068     @return         A pointer to the newly created scheduler.
01069     @see    @ref    creating_schedulers
01070 */
01071 void *scheduler_new(void);
01072 
01073 
01074 /** Make a scheduler current, so that future related calls (such as 
01075     clock_delay()) will affect the appropriate scheduler. 
01076 
01077     @ingroup        clocks
01078     @param  x       The scheduler to make current.
01079     @return         This routine returns a pointer to the previously current scheduler, 
01080                     wsaved and restored when local scheduling is complete.
01081     @see    @ref    creating_schedulers
01082 */
01083 void *scheduler_set(void *x);
01084 
01085 
01086 /** Run scheduler events to a selected time.
01087     @ingroup        clocks
01088     @param  x       The scheduler to advance.
01089     @param  until   The ending time for this run (in milliseconds). 
01090     @see    @ref    creating_schedulers
01091 */
01092 void scheduler_run(void *x, double until);
01093 
01094 
01095 /** Set the current time of the scheduler. 
01096     @ingroup        clocks
01097     @param  x       The scheduler to set.
01098     @param  time    The new current time for the selected scheduler (in milliseconds). 
01099     @see    @ref    creating_schedulers
01100 */
01101 void scheduler_settime(void *x, double time);
01102 
01103 
01104 /** Retrieve the current time of the selected scheduler.
01105     @ingroup        clocks
01106     @param  x       The scheduler to query.
01107     @param  time    The current time of the selected scheduler.
01108     @see    @ref    creating_schedulers
01109 */
01110 void scheduler_gettime(void *x, double *time);
01111 
01112 
01113 
01114 
01115 /**
01116     Cause a function to be executed at the timer level at some time in the future specified by a delay offset.
01117 
01118     @ingroup    threading
01119     @param      ob      First argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01120     @param      fun     Function to be called, see below for how it should be declared.
01121     @param      delay   The delay from the current time before the function will be executed.
01122     @param      sym     Second argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01123     @param      argc    Count of arguments in argv. argc is also the third argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01124     @param      argv    Array containing a variable number of #t_atom function arguments. 
01125                         If this argument is non-zero, defer allocates memory to make a copy of the arguments 
01126                         (according to the size passed in argc) 
01127                         and passes the copied array to the function fun when it executes as the fourth argument.
01128 
01129     @remark             schedule_delay() is similar to schedule but allows you to specify the 
01130                         time as a delay rather than a specific logical time. 
01131                         
01132                         One use of schedule() or schedule_delay() is as an alternative to 
01133                         using the lockout flag. Here is an example click method that calls 
01134                         schedule() instead of outlet_int() surrounded by lockout_set() calls.
01135 
01136     @code
01137     void myobject_click (t_myobject *x, Point pt, short modifiers) 
01138     { 
01139         t_atom a[1]; 
01140         a[0].a_type = A_LONG; 
01141         a[0].a_w.w_long = Random(); 
01142         schedule_delay(x, myobject_sched, 0 ,0, 1, a); 
01143     } 
01144 
01145     void myobject_sched (t_myobject *x, t_symbol *s, short ac, t_atom *av) 
01146     { 
01147         outlet_int(x->m_out,av->a_w.w_long); 
01148     } 
01149     @endcode
01150 
01151     @see schedule()
01152 */
01153 void schedule_delay(void *ob, method fun, long delay, t_symbol *sym, short argc, t_atom *argv);
01154 void schedule_fdelay(void *ob, method fun, double delay, t_symbol *sym, short argc, t_atom *argv);
01155 void schedule_defer(void *ob, method fun, long delay, t_symbol *sym, short argc, t_atom *arv);
01156 void schedule_fdefer(void *ob, method fun, double delay, t_symbol *sym, short argc, t_atom *arv);
01157 short lockout_set(short);
01158 
01159 /**
01160     Determine whether your code is executing in the Max scheduler thread.
01161     
01162     @ingroup    threading
01163     @return     This function returns non-zero if you are within Max's scheduler thread, zero otherwise. 
01164                 Note that if your code sets up other types of interrupt-level callbacks, 
01165                 such as for other types of device drivers used in asynchronous mode, isr will return false.
01166 */
01167 long isr(void);
01168 short isr_set(short way);
01169 
01170 
01171 
01172 // queue functions
01173 
01174 /**
01175     Create a new Qelem.
01176     The created Qelem will need to be freed using qelem_free(), do not use freeobject().
01177     
01178     @ingroup qelems
01179     @param  obj Argument to be passed to function fun when the Qelem executes. 
01180                 Normally a pointer to your object.
01181     @param  fn  Function to execute.
01182     @return     A pointer to a Qelem instance.  
01183                 You need to store this value to pass to qelem_set().
01184     
01185     @remark     Any kind of drawing or calling of Macintosh Toolbox routines that 
01186                 allocate or purge memory should be done in a Qelem function. 
01187 */
01188 void *qelem_new(void *obj, method fn);
01189 
01190 
01191 /**
01192     Cause a Qelem to execute. 
01193 
01194     @ingroup qelems
01195     @param  q   The Qelem whose function will be executed in the main thread.
01196     
01197     @remark     The key behavior of qelem_set() is this: if the Qelem object has already 
01198                 been set, it will not be set again. (If this is not what you want, see 
01199                 defer().) This is useful if you want to redraw the state of some 
01200                 data when it changes, but not in response to changes that occur faster 
01201                 than can be drawn. A Qelem object is unset after its queue function has 
01202                 been called.
01203 */
01204 void qelem_set(void *q);
01205 
01206 
01207 /**
01208     Cancel a Qelem’s execution. 
01209     If the Qelem’s function is set to be called, qelem_unset() will stop it 
01210     from being called. Otherwise, qelem_unset() does nothing.
01211 
01212     @ingroup qelems
01213     @param  q   The Qelem whose execution you wish to cancel.
01214 */
01215 void qelem_unset(void *q);
01216 
01217 
01218 /**
01219     Free a Qelem object created with qelem_new().
01220     Typically this will be in your object’s free funtion. 
01221 
01222     @ingroup qelems
01223     @param  x   The Qelem to destroy.
01224 */
01225 void qelem_free(void *x);
01226 
01227 
01228 /**
01229     Cause a Qelem to execute with a higher priority.
01230     This function is identical to qelem_set(), except that the Qelem’s 
01231     function is placed at the front of the list of routines to execute in the 
01232     main thread instead of the back. Be polite and only use 
01233     qelem_front() only for special time-critical applications.
01234         
01235     @ingroup qelems
01236     @param  x   The Qelem whose function will be executed in the main thread.
01237 */
01238 void qelem_front(void *x);
01239 
01240 
01241 /**
01242     Defer execution of a function to the main thread if (and only if) 
01243     your function is executing in the scheduler thread.
01244     
01245     @ingroup    threading
01246     @param      ob      First argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01247     @param      fn      Function to be called, see below for how it should be declared.
01248     @param      sym     Second argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01249     @param      argc    Count of arguments in argv. argc is also the third argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01250     @param      argv    Array containing a variable number of #t_atom function arguments. 
01251                         If this argument is non-zero, defer allocates memory to make a copy of the arguments 
01252                         (according to the size passed in argc) 
01253                         and passes the copied array to the function fun when it executes as the fourth argument.
01254     @return     Return values is for internal Cycling '74 use only.
01255     
01256     @remark     This function uses the isr() routine to determine whether you’re at the 
01257                 Max timer interrupt level (in the scheduler thread). 
01258                 If so, defer() creates a Qelem (see @ref qelems), calls 
01259                 qelem_front(), and its queue function calls the function fn you 
01260                 passed with the specified arguments. 
01261                 If you’re not in the scheduler thread, the function is executed immediately with the 
01262                 arguments. Note that this implies that defer() is not appropriate for 
01263                 using in situations such as Device or File manager I/0 completion routines. 
01264                 The defer_low() function is appropriate however, because it always defers. 
01265 
01266                 The deferred function should be declared as follows:
01267     @code
01268     void myobject_do (myObject *client, t_symbol *s, short argc, t_atom *argv);
01269     @endcode
01270     
01271     @see        defer_low()
01272 */
01273 void *defer(void *ob,method fn,t_symbol *sym,short argc,t_atom *argv);
01274 
01275 
01276 /**
01277     Defer execution of a function to the back of the queue on the main thread.
01278 
01279     @ingroup    threading
01280     @param      ob      First argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01281     @param      fn      Function to be called, see below for how it should be declared.
01282     @param      sym     Second argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01283     @param      argc    Count of arguments in argv. argc is also the third argument passed to the function fun when it executes.
01284     @param      argv    Array containing a variable number of #t_atom function arguments. 
01285                         If this argument is non-zero, defer allocates memory to make a copy of the arguments 
01286                         (according to the size passed in argc) 
01287                         and passes the copied array to the function fun when it executes as the fourth argument.
01288     @return     Return values is for internal Cycling '74 use only.
01289 
01290     @remark     defer_low() always defers a call to the function fun whether you are already 
01291                 in the main thread or not, and uses qelem_set(), not qelem_front(). This 
01292                 function is recommended for responding to messages that will cause 
01293                 your object to open a dialog box, such as read and write. 
01294 
01295                 The deferred function should be declared as follows:
01296     @code
01297     void myobject_do (myObject *client, t_symbol *s, short argc, t_atom *argv);
01298     @endcode
01299 
01300     @see        defer()
01301 */
01302 void *defer_low(void *ob,method fn,t_symbol *sym,short argc,t_atom *argv);
01303 
01304 void *defer_medium(void *ob, method fn, t_symbol *sym, short argc, t_atom *argv);
01305 
01306 void *defer_front(void *ob, method fn, t_symbol *sym, short argc, t_atom *argv);
01307 
01308 // private
01309 void *defer_sys_low(void *ob,method fn,t_symbol *sym,short argc,t_atom *argv);
01310 
01311 
01312 
01313 // binbuf functions
01314 
01315 /**
01316     Use binbuf_new() to create and initialize a Binbuf.
01317     @ingroup    binbuf
01318     @return     Returns a new binbuf if successful, otherwise NULL.
01319 */
01320 void *binbuf_new(void);
01321 
01322 
01323 /**
01324     Use binbuf_vinsert() to append a Max message to a Binbuf adding a semicolon.
01325     @ingroup binbuf
01326     
01327     @param  x       Binbuf containing the desired Atom. 
01328     @param  fmt     A C-string containing one or more letters corresponding to the types of each element of the message. 
01329                     s for #t_symbol*, l for long, or f for float.
01330     @param  ...     Elements of the message, passed directly to the function as Symbols, longs, or floats.
01331     
01332     @remark binbuf_vinsert() works somewhat like a printf() for Binbufs. It 
01333     allows you to pass a number of arguments of different types and insert 
01334     them into a Binbuf. The entire message will then be terminated with a 
01335     semicolon. Only 16 items can be passed to binbuf_vinsert(). 
01336     
01337     The example below shows the implementation of a normal object’s 
01338     save method. The save method requires that you build a message that 
01339     begins with #N (the new object) , followed by the name of your object 
01340     (in this case, represented by the #t_symbol myobject), followed by any 
01341     arguments your instance creation function requires. In this example, 
01342     we save the values of two fields m_val1 and m_val2 defined as longs. 
01343     
01344     @code
01345     void myobject_save (myObject *x, Binbuf *dstBuf) 
01346     { 
01347         binbuf_vinsert(dstBuf, "ssll", gensym("#N"), 
01348             gensym("myobject"), 
01349             x->m_val1, x->m_val2); 
01350     }
01351     @endcode
01352     
01353     Suppose that such an object had written this data into a file. If you 
01354     opened the file as text, you would see the following: 
01355     
01356     @code
01357     #N myobject 10 20; 
01358     #P newobj 218 82 30 myobject; 
01359     @endcode
01360     
01361     The first line will result in a new myobject object to be created; the 
01362     creation function receives the arguments 10 and 20. The second line 
01363     contains the text of the object box. The newobj message to a patcher 
01364     creates the object box user interface object and attaches it to the 
01365     previously created myobject object. Normally, the newex message is 
01366     used. This causes the object to be created using the arguments that 
01367     were typed into the object box.
01368 */
01369 void binbuf_vinsert(void *x, char *fmt, ...);
01370 
01371 
01372 /**
01373     Use binbuf_insert() to append a Max message to a Binbuf adding a semicolon.
01374     @ingroup binbuf
01375     
01376     @param  x       Binbuf to receive the items. 
01377     @param  s       Ignored. Pass NULL.
01378     @param  argc    Count of items in the argv array. 
01379     @param  argv    Array of t_atoms to add to the Binbuf. 
01380     
01381     @remark You’ll use binbuf_insert() instead of binbuf_append() if you were 
01382     saving your object into a Binbuf and wanted a semicolon at the end. If 
01383     the message is part of a file that will later be evaluated, such as a 
01384     Patcher file, the first argument argv[0] will be the receiver of the 
01385     message and must be a Symbol. binbuf_vinsert() is 
01386     easier to use than binbuf_insert(), since you don’t have to format 
01387     your data into an array of Atoms first. 
01388     
01389     binbuf_insert() will also convert the t_symbols #1 through #9 into 
01390     $1 through $9. This is used for saving patcher files that take 
01391     arguments; you will probably never save these symbols as part of 
01392     anything you are doing.
01393 */
01394 void binbuf_insert(void *x, t_symbol *s, short argc, t_atom *argv);
01395 
01396 
01397 /**
01398     Use binbuf_eval to evaluate a Max message in a Binbuf, passing it arguments.
01399     binbuf_eval() is an advanced function that evaluates the message in a 
01400     Binbuf with arguments in argv, and sends it to receiver.
01401                     
01402     @ingroup binbuf
01403     @param  x   Binbuf containing the message.
01404     @param  ac  Count of items in the argv array.
01405     @param  av  Array of t_atoms as the arguments to the message. 
01406     @param  to  Receiver of the message. 
01407 
01408     @return     The result of sending the message.
01409 */
01410 void *binbuf_eval(void *x, short ac, t_atom *av, void *to);
01411 
01412 
01413 /**
01414     Use binbuf_getatom to retrieve a single Atom from a Binbuf.
01415     
01416     @ingroup binbuf
01417     @param  x   Binbuf containing the desired #t_atom. 
01418     @param  p1  Offset into the Binbuf’s array of types. Modified to point to the next #t_atom.
01419     @param  p2  Offset into the Binbuf’s array of data. Modified to point to the next #t_atom.
01420     @param  ap  Location of a #t_atom where the retrieved data will be placed.
01421     
01422     @return     1 if there were no t_atoms at the specified offsets, 
01423                 0 if there’s a legitimate t_atom returned in result.
01424                 
01425     @remark     To get the first t_atom, set both typeOffset and stuffOffset to 0.
01426                 Here’s an example of getting all the items in a Binbuf: 
01427     @code
01428     t_atom holder; 
01429     long to, so; 
01430     
01431     to = 0; 
01432     so = 0; 
01433     while (!binbuf_getatom(x, &to, &so, &holder)){
01434         // do something with the t_atom
01435     }
01436     @endcode
01437 */
01438 short binbuf_getatom(void *x, long *p1, long *p2, t_atom *ap);
01439 
01440 
01441 /**
01442     Use binbuf_text() to convert a text handle to a Binbuf.
01443     binbuf_text() parses the text in the handle srcText and converts it 
01444     into binary format. Use it to evaluate a text file or text line entry into a 
01445     Binbuf.
01446     
01447     @ingroup binbuf
01448     @param  x       Binbuf to contain the converted text. 
01449                     It must have already been created with binbuf_new. 
01450                     Its previous contents are destroyed.
01451     @param  srcText Handle to the text to be converted. It need not be terminated with a 0.
01452     @param  n       Number of characters in the text. 
01453     @return         If binbuf_text encounters an error during its operation, 
01454                     a non-zero result is returned, otherwise it returns 0.
01455     
01456     @remark         Note: Commas, symbols containing a dollar sign followed by a number 
01457                     1-9, and semicolons are identified by special pseudo-type constants for 
01458                     you when your text is binbuf-ized. 
01459                     
01460                     The following constants in the a_type field of Atoms returned by 
01461                     binbuf_getAtom identify the special symbols #A_SEMI, 
01462                     #A_COMMA, and #A_DOLLAR. 
01463                     
01464                     For a #t_atom of the pseudo-type #A_DOLLAR, the a_w.w_long field of 
01465                     the #t_atom contains the number after the dollar sign in the original 
01466                     text or symbol. 
01467                     
01468                     Using these pseudo-types may be helpful in separating “sentences” and 
01469                     “phrases” in the input language you design. For example, the old pop-up 
01470                     umenu object allowed users to have spaces in between words by requiring 
01471                     the menu items be separated by commas. It’s reasonably easy, using 
01472                     binbuf_getatom(), to find the commas in a Binbuf in order to 
01473                     determine the beginning of a new item when reading the atomized text 
01474                     to be displayed in the menu.
01475                      
01476                     If you want to use a literal comma or semicolon in a symbol, precede it 
01477                     with a backslash (\\) character. The backslash character can be included 
01478                     by using two backslashes in a row.
01479 */
01480 short binbuf_text(void *x, char **srcText, long n);
01481 
01482 
01483 /**
01484     Use binbuf_totext() to convert a Binbuf into a text handle.
01485     binbuf_totext() converts a Binbuf into text and places it in a handle. 
01486     Backslashes are added to protect literal commas and semicolons 
01487     contained in symbols. The pseudo-types are converted into commas, 
01488     semicolons, or dollar-sign and number, without backslashes preceding 
01489     them. binbuf_text can read the output of binbuf_totext and 
01490     make the same Binbuf.
01491         
01492     @ingroup binbuf
01493     @param  x       Binbuf with data to convert to text.
01494     @param  dstText Pre-existing handle where the text will be placed. 
01495                     dstText will be resized to accomodate the text. 
01496     @param  sizep   Where binbuf_totext() returns the number of characters in the converted text handle.
01497     @return         If binbuf_totext runs out of memory during its operation, it returns a non-zero result, 
01498                     otherwise it returns 0.
01499 */
01500 short binbuf_totext(void *x, char **dstText, long *sizep);
01501 
01502 
01503 /**
01504     Use binbuf_set() to change the entire contents of a Binbuf. 
01505     The previous contents of the Binbuf are destroyed.
01506 
01507     @ingroup binbuf
01508     @param  x       Binbuf to receive the items.
01509     @param  s       Ignored. Pass NULL.
01510     @param  argc    Count of items in the argv array.
01511     @param  argv    Array of t_atoms to put in the Binbuf.
01512 */
01513 void binbuf_set(void *x, t_symbol *s, short argc, t_atom *argv);

01524 void binbuf_append(void *x, t_symbol *s, short argc, t_atom *argv);

01536 
01537 /**
01538     Use readatom() to read a single Atom from a text buffer.
01539     @ingroup        binbuf
01540     @param  outstr  C-string of 256 characters that will receive the next text item read from the buffer.
01541     @param  text    Handle to the text buffer to be read.
01542     @param  n       Starts at 0, and is modified by readatom to point to the next item in the text buffer. 
01543     @param  e       Number of characters in text.
01544     @param  ap      Where the resulting Atom read from the text buffer is placed.
01545     @return         readatom() returns non-zero if there is more text to read, 
01546                     and zero if it has reached the end of the text. 
01547                     Note that this return value has the opposite logic from that of binbuf_getatom().
01548     
01549     @remark         This function provides access to the low-level Max text evaluator used 
01550                     by binbuf_text(). It is designed to operate on a handle of characters 
01551                     (text) and called in a loop, as in the example shown below.
01552     @code
01553     long index = 0; 
01554     t_atom dst; 
01555     char outstr[256]; 
01556     
01557     while (readatom(outstr,textHandle,&index,textLength,&dst)) 
01558     { 
01559         // do something with the resulting Atom
01560     } 
01561     @endcode
01562     
01563     @remark         An alternative to using readatom is to turn your text into a Binbuf 
01564                     using binbuf_text(), then call binbuf_getatom() in a loop.
01565 */
01566 short readatom(char *outstr, char **text, long *n, long e, t_atom *ap);
01567 char *atom_string(t_atom *a);

01612 // message functions
01613 
01614 /** Send a typed message directly to a Max object.
01615     @ingroup class_old
01616     
01617     @param op   Max object that will receive the message. 
01618     @param msg  The message selector. 
01619     @param argc Count of message arguments in argv. 
01620     @param argp Array of t_atoms; the message arguments. 
01621     @return     If the receiver object can respond to the message, 
01622                 typedmess() returns the result. Otherwise, an error message will be 
01623                 seen in the Max window and 0 will be returned.
01624     
01625     @remark typedmess sends a message to a Max object (receiver) a message 
01626         with arguments. Note that the message 
01627         must be a #t_symbol, not a character string, so you must call gensym 
01628         on a string before passing it to typedmess. Also, note that untyped 
01629         messages defined for classes with the argument list #A_CANT cannot be 
01630         sent using typedmess. You must use getfn() etc. instead. 
01631         
01632         Example: 
01633     @code
01634     //If you want to send a bang message to the object bang_me… 
01635     void *bangResult; 
01636     bangResult = typedmess(bang_me,gensym("bang"),0,0L);
01637     @endcode
01638 */
01639 void *typedmess(t_object *op, t_symbol *msg, short argc, t_atom *argp);
01640 
01641 
01642 /** Use getfn() to send an untyped message to a Max object with error checking.
01643     @ingroup class_old
01644     
01645     @param op   Receiver of the message.
01646     @param msg  Message selector.
01647     @return     getfn returns a pointer to the method bound to the message selector 
01648                 msg in the receiver’s message list. It returns 0 and prints an error 
01649                 message in Max Window if the method can’t be found.
01650 */
01651 method getfn(t_object *op, t_symbol *msg);
01652 
01653 
01654 /** Use egetfn() to send an untyped message to a Max object that always works.
01655     @ingroup class_old
01656     
01657     @param op   Receiver of the message.
01658     @param msg  Message selector.
01659     @return     egetfn returns a pointer to the method bound to the message selector 
01660                 msg in the receiver’s message list. If the method can’t be found, a 
01661                 pointer to a do-nothing function is returned.
01662 */
01663 method egetfn(t_object *op, t_symbol *msg);
01664 
01665 
01666 /** Use zgetfn() to send an untyped message to a Max object without error checking.
01667     @ingroup class_old
01668     
01669     @param op   Receiver of the message.
01670     @param msg  Message selector.
01671     @return     zgetfn returns a pointer to the method bound to the message selector 
01672                 msg in the receiver’s message list. It returns 0 but doesn’t print an 
01673                 error message in Max Window if the method can’t be found.
01674 */
01675 method zgetfn(t_object *op, t_symbol *msg);

01730 /** Get a handle to the data in a named table object.
01731     @ingroup tables
01732     
01733     @param s    Symbol containing the name of the table object to find.
01734     @param hp   Address of a handle where the table’s data will be returned if the named table object is found.
01735     @param sp   Number of elements in the table (its size in longs). 
01736     @return     If no table object is associated with the symbol tableName, table_get() returns a non-zero result.
01737     
01738     @remark     table_get searches for a table associated with the t_symbol 
01739                 tableName. If one is found, a Handle to its elements (stored as an 
01740                 array of long integers) is returned and the function returns 0. 
01741                 Never count on a table to exist across calls to 
01742                 one of your methods. Call table_get and check the result each time 
01743                 you wish to use a table. 
01744     
01745                 Here is an example of retrieving the 40th element of a table: 
01746     @code
01747     long **storage,size,value; 
01748     if (!table_get(gensym("somename"),&storage,&size)) { 
01749         if (size > 40) 
01750             value = *((*storage)+40); 
01751     }
01752     @endcode
01753 */
01754 short table_get(t_symbol *s, long ***hp, long *sp);
01755

01757 /** Mark a table object as having changed data.
01758     @ingroup tables
01759     @param s    Symbol containing the name of a table object.
01760     @return     If no table is associated with tableName, table_dirty returns a non-zero result.
01761 */
01762 short table_dirty(t_symbol *s);

01773 // file functions
01774 
01775 /** Load a data file into a handle.
01776     This is a low-level routine used for reading text and data files. You 
01777         specify the file’s name and Path ID, as well as a pointer to a Handle.
01778 
01779     @ingroup loading_max_files
01780     @param  name    Name of the patcher file to load. 
01781     @param  volume  Path ID specifying the location of the file.
01782     @param  h       Pointer to a handle variable that will receive the handle 
01783                     that contains the data in the file.
01784     @param  sizep   Size of the handle returned in h. 
01785     @return         If the file is found, readtohandle creates a Handle, reads all the data in 
01786                     the file into it, assigns the handle to the variable hp, and returns the 
01787                     size of the data in size. readtohandle returns 0 if the file was 
01788                     opened and read successfully, and non-zero if there was an error.
01789 */
01790 short readtohandle(char *name, short volume, char ***h, long *sizep);

01792 
01793 /** Load a patcher file by name and volume reference number.
01794     @ingroup loading_max_files
01795     @param  name    Filename of the patcher file to load (C string). 
01796     @param  vol     Path ID specifying the location of the file.
01797     @return         If the file is found, fileload tries to open 
01798                     the file, evaluate it, open a window, and bring it to the front. A pointer 
01799                     to the newly created Patcher is returned if loading is successful, 
01800                     otherwise, if the file is not found or there is insufficient memory, zero 
01801                     is returned.
01802 */
01803 void *fileload(char *name, short vol);
01804 
01805 
01806 /** Pass arguments to Max files when you open them.
01807     This function loads the specified file and returns a pointer to the 
01808     created object. Historically, intload() is was used to open patcher files, 
01809     whether they are in text or Max binary format. 
01810     It could also open table files whose contents begin with the word “table.” 
01811     
01812     @ingroup loading_max_files
01813     @param  name        Name of the file to open. 
01814     @param  volume      Path ID specifying the location of the file. 
01815     @param  s           A symbol.
01816     @param  ac          Count of t_atoms in av. To properly open a patcher file, ac should be 9. 
01817     @param  av          Array of t_atoms that will replace the changeable 
01818                         arguments 1-9. The default behavior could be to set 
01819                         all these to t_atoms of type #A_LONG with a value of 0.
01820     @param  couldedit   If non-zero and the file is not a patcher file, the file is opened as a text file.
01821     @return             If couldedit is non-zero and the file is not a patcher file, it is made into 
01822                         a text editor, and lowload returns 0. If couldedit is non-zero, lowload
01823                         will just alert the user to an error and return 0. If there is no error, the 
01824                         value returned will be a pointer to a patcher or table object. 
01825 */
01826 void *intload(char *name, short volume, t_symbol *s, short ac, t_atom *av, short couldedit);
01827 
01828 
01829 /** Load a patcher file located in the Max search path by name.
01830     This function searches for a patcher file, opens it, 
01831     evaluates it as a patcher file, opens a window for the patcher and brings 
01832     it to the front. You need only specify a filename and Max will look 
01833     through its search path for the file. The search path begins with the 
01834     current “default volume” that is often the volume of the last opened 
01835     patcher file, then the folders specified in the File Preferences dialog, 
01836     searched depth first, then finally the folder that contains the Max 
01837     application.
01838 
01839     @ingroup loading_max_files
01840     @param  name    Filename of the patcher file to load (C string).
01841     @return         If stringload() returns a non-zero result, you can later 
01842                     use freeobject() to close the patcher, or just let users do it themselves. 
01843                     If stringload() returns zero, no file with the specified name was 
01844                     found or there was insufficient memory to open it.
01845 */
01846 void *stringload(char *name);
01847 
01848 void *resource_install(char *name, long rsrc);
01849 void *toolfile_new(char *name, short vol, long type);
01850 long toolfile_fread(void *t, char *buf, long n);
01851 long toolfile_fwrite(void *t, char *buf, long n);
01852 short toolfile_getc(void *t);
01853 short collective_load(char *name, short vol, short argc, t_atom *argv);
01854 void *onecopy_fileload(char *s, short path);

01862 // preset functions
01863 
01864 /** Give the preset object a general message to restore the current state of your object.
01865     This is a general preset function for use when your object’s state 
01866     cannot be restored with a simple int or set message. The example 
01867     below shows the expected format for specifying what your current 
01868     state is to a preset object. The first thing you supply is your object itself, 
01869     followed by the symbol that is the name of your object’s class (which 
01870     you can retrieve from your object using the macro ob_sym, declared in 
01871     ext_mess.h). Next, supply the symbol that specifies the message you 
01872     want receive (a method for which had better be defined in your class), 
01873     followed by the arguments to this message—the current values of your 
01874     object’s fields.
01875 
01876     @ingroup presets
01877     @param  fmt     C string containing one or more letters corresponding 
01878                     to the types of each element of the message. s for 
01879                     Symbol, l for long, or f for float.
01880     @param  ...     Elements of the message used to restore the state of 
01881                     your object, passed directly to the function as Symbols, 
01882                     longs, or floats. See below for an example that 
01883                     conforms to what the preset object expects.
01884 */
01885 void preset_store(char *fmt, ... /*struct b100 arg1 */);
01886 
01887 
01888 /** Restore the state of your object with a set message.
01889     This function causes a set message with the argument value to be sent 
01890     to your object from the preset object when the user executes a preset.
01891 
01892     @ingroup presets    
01893     @param  obj     Your object.
01894     @param  val     Current value of your object.
01895     
01896 */
01897 void preset_set(t_object *obj, long val);
01898 
01899 
01900 /** Restore the state of your object with an int message.
01901     This function causes an int message with the argument value to be 
01902     sent to your object from the preset object when the user executes a 
01903     preset. All of the existing user interface objects use the int message for 
01904     restoring their state when a preset is executed. 
01905 
01906     @ingroup presets    
01907     @param  x   Your object.
01908     @param  n   Current value of your object.
01909 */
01910 void preset_int(void *x,long n);

01940 // proxy functions
01941 
01942 /**
01943     Use proxy_new to create a new Proxy object. 
01944     
01945     @ingroup inout
01946     @param  x           Your object. 
01947     @param  id          A non-zero number to be written into your object when a message is received in this particular Proxy.
01948                         Normally, id will be the inlet “number” analogous to in1, in2 etc. 
01949     @param  stuffloc    A pointer to a location where the id value will be written.
01950     @return             A pointer to the new proxy inlet.
01951     
01952     @remark     This routine creates a new Proxy object (that includes an inlet). It 
01953                 allows you to identify messages based on an id value stored in the 
01954                 location specified by stuffLoc. You should store the pointer 
01955                 returned by proxy_new() because you’ll need to free all Proxies in your 
01956                 object’s free function using object_free(). 
01957                 
01958                 After your method has finished, Proxy sets the stuffLoc location 
01959                 back to 0, since it never sees messages coming in an object’s leftmost 
01960                 inlet. You’ll know you received a message in the leftmost inlet if the 
01961                 contents of stuffLoc is 0. As of Max 4.3, stuffLoc is not always 
01962                 guaranteed to be a correct indicator of the inlet in which a message was 
01963                 received. Use proxy_getinlet() to determine the inlet number.   
01964 */
01965 void *proxy_new(void *x,long id,long *stuffloc);
01966 
01967 
01968 /**
01969     Use proxy_getinlet to get the inlet number in which a message was received.
01970     Note that the “owner” argument should point to your external object’s instance, not a proxy object.
01971 
01972     @ingroup inout
01973     @param  master  Your object. 
01974     @return         The index number of the inlet that received the message.
01975 */
01976 long proxy_getinlet(t_object *master);

01991 /**
01992     Register a function that will be called when Max exits.
01993 
01994     @ingroup misc
01995     @param  m   A function that will be called on Max exit.
01996     @param  a   Argument to be used with method m.
01997     
01998     @remark     quittask_install() provides a mechanism for your external to 
01999     register a routine to be called prior to Max shutdown. This is useful for 
02000     objects that need to provide disk-based persistance outside the 
02001     standard Max storage mechanisms, or need to shut down hardware or 
02002     their connection to system software and cannot do so in the 
02003     termination routine of a code fragment.
02004 */
02005 void quittask_install(method m, void *a);
02006 
02007 
02008 /**
02009     Unregister a function previously registered with quittask_install().
02010 
02011     @ingroup misc
02012     @param  m   Function to be removed as a shutdown method.
02013 */
02014 void quittask_remove(method m);
02015 void quittask_remove2(method m, void *a);

02038 
02039 // miscellaneous functions
02040 
02041 /**
02042     Determine version information about the current Max environment.
02043 
02044     This function returns the version number of Max. In Max versions 
02045     2.1.4 and later, this number is the version number of the Max kernel 
02046     application in binary-coded decimal. Thus, 2.1.4 would return 214 hex 
02047     or 532 decimal. Version 3.0 returns 300 hex. 
02048     
02049     Use this to check for the existence of particular function macros that are only present in more 
02050     recent Max versions. Versions before 2.1.4 returned 1, except for 
02051     versions 2.1.1 - 2.1.3 which returned 2. 
02052     
02053     Bit 14 (counting from left) will 
02054     be set if Max is running as a standalone application, so you should 
02055     mask the lower 12 bits to get the version number.
02056         
02057     @ingroup    misc
02058     @return     The Max environment's version number.
02059 */
02060 short maxversion(void);
02061 
02062 
02063 /** Get a unique number for each Patcher file saved.
02064     This function returns a serial number that is incremented each time a 
02065     Patcher file is saved. This routine is useful for objects like table and coll 
02066     that have multiple objects that refer to the same data, and can “embed” 
02067     the data inside a Patcher file. If the serial number hasn’t changed since 
02068     your object was last saved, you can detect this and avoid saving 
02069     multiple copies of the object’s data.
02070 
02071     @ingroup evnum
02072     @return The serial number.
02073 */
02074 long serialno(void);

02136 /** Create a new filewatcher.
02137     The file will not be actively watched until filewatcher_start() is called.
02138     The filewatcher can be freed using object_free().
02139     
02140     @ingroup            files
02141     @param  owner       Your object.  
02142                         This object will receive the message "filechanged" when the watcher sees a change in the file or folder.
02143     @param  path        The path in which the file being watched resides, or the path of the folder being watched.
02144     @param  filename    The name of the file being watched, or an empty string if you are simply watching the folder specified by path.
02145     @return             A pointer to the new filewatcher.
02146     @remark             The "filechanged" method should have the prototype:
02147     @code
02148     void myObject_filechanged(t_myObject *x, char *filename, short path);
02149     @endcode
02150     */
02151 void *filewatcher_new(t_object *owner, short path, char *filename);
02152 
02153 /** Start watching a file using a filewatcher created with filewatcher_new().
02154     @param  x           A filewatcher pointer, as returned by filewatcher_new().    */
02155 void filewatcher_start(void *x);
02156 
02157 /** Stop watching a file using a filewatcher created with filewatcher_new().
02158     @param  x           A filewatcher pointer, as returned by filewatcher_new().    */
02159 void filewatcher_stop(void *x);
